node.text:
#farmhousecheddar with #chives. Some of you may know of my difficulties with #makingcheese with Jez’s milk. #Ilovemycow but she has really poor curd yield. This time I used 2 big pots and 19L of milk to get a final weight of 1.4kg. It was not as difficult as I thought it might be to  stir and monitor 2 pots at the same time but it was by no means #supereasybarelyaninconvenience.I’m looking forward to when my smaller moulds come. 

I also was able to use my new #phmeter to hit acid targets and to see if I can make cheese taste like it supposed to taste. Now to wait a few months for maturity!
.
.
.
#bluedogfarmmetchosin #metchosin #metchosinbc #familycow #familymilkcow #diycheese #homemadecheese #smallfarm #smallfarms #smallscalefarming #makeyourownfood #organicfed

Homesteader + farmer + Mama = a major multitasker 💪👩‍🌾

@farmstandrevival’s NEWEST Featured Farm: 👍 @the_frenchiefarm

“Frenchie Farm is an organic and regenerative family farm raising Nigerian Dwarf goats, Great Pyrenees, and pasture raised chickens, ducks, and broiler chickens. We provide farm classes for kids dedicated to teaching children about sustainable farming. Frenchie Farm also sells seasonally appropriate farm-to-table goods, including but not limited to, pasture raised chicken + duck eggs, pasture raised broiler chickens, honey, and seasonal produce.”

In an effort to live a more simplified life with intention and gratitude, our family made the decision to pursue modern homesteading. We grow as much of our own food as possible in our garden while also raising Nigerian Dwarf goats, chickens, and bees.”

Chicago, Illinois

node.text:
[MÂCHE-PATATE #50 🎉 - On y est : 50e épisode et 60e invité!] 
Relever des défis et multiplier les outils pour faire avancer la cause de l'agriculture sur petite surface? C'est ce qui nourrit @jeanmartinfortier, @themarketgardeners, agriculteur, formateur et consultant, qui a récemment lancé le magazine @growersandco. 
 
Il n'y a pas si longtemps, les jeunes étaient peu nombreux à aller étudier en agriculture. Aujourd'hui, les programmes d'agriculture biologique sont contingentés. C'est que, comme pour toute cause sociale, une bonne dose de leadership et une touche de marketing ont réussi à redorer le blason du métier d'agriculteur. 
 
Ce travail, on le doit notamment à l'énergie inépuisable de Jean-Martin Fortier et à son envie de faire bouger les choses. Et au-delà du transfert de connaissances techniques, cet ambassadeur a envie de célébrer la beauté de son métier et de rappeler que malgré les obstacles du quotidien, les cultivateurs et cultivatrices sont en train de changer le monde! 🙌 
 
On profite aussi de notre 50e épisode pour faire un petit bilan et revenir sur nos coups de coeur du projet! 💚 
.
.
.
(Photo : Growers & Co.)
.
.
#agriculture #agriculturebio #maraîchage #maraicher #agriculturequebec #organicfarming #smallscalefarming #marketgardener #marketgardening #changerlemonde

node.text:
We’re kicking off something new today for @como.gives: #WorkingLandsWednesday! Every Wednesday, we’ll have some fun information relating to working landscapes in Mid-Missouri. 

For starters, did you know that these Birch Cove Farm sheep are heroes to birds and fish? It’s true! By helping establish native grasses and remediate the effects of strip mining, these cuties are reducing runoff, improving the pH of waterways, and helping to provide habitat for grassland bird species! What we do to live on these landscapes doesn’t have to be destructive, it can be restorative!
.
.

node.text:
For thousands of years a diverse spectrum of cultures have been looking to plants for the medicine that would heal us. But what if there is a more profound medicine for health in the soil? And how could it be any other way? Really, if you look at the way that biology happens, soil is the crossroads of fresh water and microbiome-delivered nutrient delivery that is the foundation for all multi-cellular life.

We have destroyed an estimated 97% of native agricultural soils around the world in the last 50 years. To regenerate the soil is to regenerate human life and reverse our self-engineered earth extinction.

Learn more @farmersfootprint . . . . .

* Repost @zachbushmd *

node.text:
Today we moved a few sheep around the farm. It’s nice to have the gates open for a while! For a time there we had 3 or 4 gates between our cottage and the garden. Today was Sage’s first time in the yards and she was curiously walking the race and climbing the gates to watch the lambs bleating to their mums outside. We spent some time here, then in the garden and finished the day off with a birthday drink at a local winery with some friends after kindy pickup.
These days, more than ever, we couldn’t be happier to call this place home.

node.text:
We got a Vortex baby! An investment we've been considering for a while! We don't often buy "new stuff", but this is gonna earn its keep and enable us to make soooo many awesome new delights #offgrid on the farm!
.
This @gsioutdoors manual Vortex Blender is freaking awesome! We can make hummus, nut butters, smoothies, velvety soups, and baby food! @suziejanenimmo looks happy right, but I'm fully loosing my shit behind the camera 😂😂😂 VEGAN CHEESE CAKE!!!! If you've ever been catered for by @ahimsaplanthealing you'll understand!
.
I recently showed Suzie the "Urban Homestead" video on YouTube that inspired me so much almost a decade ago now, and she spotted one on their kitchen counter too! Feels pretty dam epic too now be living a life we've been dreaming of for so long.
.
Has anyone else ever used one of these? What's your favourite thing to make?
.
.
.

node.text:
Melbourne friends, if you can’t get to us, we will come to you!

After receiving much love and interest from city dwellers and tree change dreamers, we have begun delivering to Melbourne! We are so excited to share our beautiful region with you.

We will deliver fresh local produce straight from the farm, forest, vineyard and kitchens. You won’t find these goods at your local grocer, as they often go straight to restaurants, farm gates and locals.

Orders close tonight for delivery Friday, and numbers are limited - as you can imagine - these are small scale, passionate producers doing what they love and creating exceptional results. 

Check us out at www.macedonrangesproduce.com.au

📷 @visitmacedonranges

node.text:
Ashwagandha- a love story.
planting//harvesting

This has been my 4th year growing Ashwagandha from seed!🤗 I sow them in seed trays on the soil surface in March, and keep them protected from the cold in a greenhouse.

Ashwagandha is easy af grow, it's in the nightshade family (eggplant, tomatoes, peppers) so has the same growing season and conditions as these favorites. This also means it has similar pests (curse you flea beetles and tomato horn worms).

I harvest the root in the fall, after we get a couple good cold snaps and the green aireal parts start to die back. Harvesting in the fall ensures that the plant has put its energy/resources back into the roots. When you see crispy skeleton plants, they're most likely not dead. They go inward to conserve their energy in order to supply their roots with enough food/sugars to last the winter. 

This is one reson why carrots are much sweeter after a frost- more sugars are developed and the nutrients are directed down into the roots. Early Spring before plants get big and leafy is also a great time to harvest roots. Tip: when harvesting roots I prefer a digging fork to a shovel! Shovels can slice the roots 👎

My half hiatus from herbalism/my business has been really healthy for me. Burnout is real y'all. Harvesting Ashwagandha helped me remember why I love this process so much, and long intricate processes in general. Nothing connects me to place and grounds me more than working with plants and getting my hands dirty. Nothing has fulfilled that sense of purpose and meaning more. But that doesn't mean burn out can't happen 🤪

Even though I'm taking some big steps back to relearn and revision, I will always find safety and ritual in the plant and animal world. Better things are ahead from myself and Wildkrafted Kitchen! I am really excited for the future and continuing this work.

 For now I'm gonna take a hint from perennial plants: use winter to go inward, set some goals, revision, and most importantly- nourish & feed my body and soul. I hope you all can do the same this winter ❤️

#herbalism #growyourown #womenwhofarm #smallscalefarming #medicinalherbs  #ashwagandha #adaptogens #gardening #holistichealth

node.text: I am frequently asked what I do with my large flock to keep them healthy, as I am in eggs from my ladies year round and rarely lose birds (knock on wood). There are a few scientific tricks for eggs through winter, like a higher protein feed to make up for free ranged protein sources going away in the winter and supplemental lighting (though many prefer to give their hens a natural break over the winter, and that preference is absolutely fine and perfectly logical, too!). One of the major issues to deal with in the cold and damp is respiratory health. Chickens with chronic upper respiratory struggles do not lay well—if I had a permanent cold I would not feel like working either. Making sure your flock has a clean, dry and well ventilated space, as well as a break from the wind is a great step toward wintering your flock. I clean my poultry space top to bottom once a week, year round. I also use oregano (enjoyed by Green One the isa brown in my photo) preventatively. Oregano has many studied benefits—it is naturally anti inflammatory and has antibiotic properties, among other benefits. I topdress their fermented food with flakes as well as sprinkle it into their water when I know extreme weather is ahead. (I buy it in bulk on Amazon.) I am not at all against using antibiotics when appropriate and have and will definitely do so as needed. With chickens as not only extreme prey animals but also in a strict pecking order easily shifted by demonstrating weakness, often by the time they are actually showing symptoms they have likely been ill for a while and are past the point of natural remedies. So I try hard to prevent illness from occurring in the first place by general good husbandry. Our turkeys however, are a lot harder to keep healthier than our chickens, for whatever reason! I was warned when I first got turkeys that they are more fragile than chickens, which seems so strange—more on that subject later!

node.text:
A mayor issue land and human rights defenders face is criminalisation. They might be smallscale farmers, displaced peasants or indigenous people who want access to their land. But big land owners, armed groups and corporations threaten or harass them, burn their belongings or kill them, bring them to court and make sure everyone around is intimidated. 

"PBI has found that women defenders of land, territory and the environment in Honduras are in a particularly vulnerable situation."

As in our project, the report does not try to diminish the role men play in defending the land. It just creates visibility around women defenders, which often lacks, and thereby creates a space in which solutions and protection can be found that take into consideration the specific circumstances of women.

Check out the @pbihonduras  report, it is very interesting. The credit for the picture goes to them. #righttofood #righttolife #righttoland #humanrightsdefenders #foodsovereignty #smallscalefarming #peacebuilding

node.text:
I took a chance and travelled across the world in the midst of a pandemic to visit the farmers who grow our crop - because it felt like the right thing to do.

Today I met Gita. She’s been living on the land and learned the traditional method of roasting Makhanas when she was a young girl.

She’s one of the wonderful women  here who insist on quality. She *hand roasts* and *hand sorts* several dozen kgs every day during harvest.

I’m incredibly impressed and didn’t appreciate how tedious and tremendous this task is, till now. It takes endless hours of working over a hot open fire to roast each seed by hand in small batches.

I saw the love and care she puts into each handful - it left me absolutely inspired. To keep building Dear Snackers - for the farmers - for our beloved Snackers- and for the love of our shared planet 💚

node.text:
Why your snails are dying

Happy new month everyone! We pray that this would be your best month yet🙏🙏

We've noticed that this is a common issue faced by a lot of snail farmers and as usual, we want to help you out🤗

These are some reasons why your snails may be dying:

-Feeding them spoilt and contaminated feeds: 
We would like you reading this to carry out this experiment. Get 3 days old beans, cold noodles, maltina and 2 weeks old egusi soup. Now mix these foods and eat it. Hmmmmm. 3 hours from when you're done, send us a DM of how you feel 😏. Exactly! The same harm this mixture will cause to you is what it'll cause to your snails. Please do not feed your snails rotten or contaminated mixtures or feed.
It will cause them to fall sick and die.
Feed them with fresh and quality feeds.

-Stress due to transportation: Most snail farmers do not take packaging and transportation serious when delivering snails to new farmers and this is a very important factor.
If this aspect is not considered thoroughly, it could lead to high mortality within few days of start up. Do not:
* Package snails in containers without air holes.
* Put snails on a hot platform or close to the vehicle's engine during transit.
* Over stack too many snails in a confined space.
* Forget to place a munching material (Paw paw or plantain leaves) in the basket or container.
* Hesitate to place snails on a balanced/ flat platform when delivering them.

-Pest and predators.
So many farmers lose their snails to ants and other pests they fail to take notice of. Make sure you thoroughly inspect your pens regularly and fix possible loopholes when one is found. You can also check out our last post on how to checkmate pest invasion on your farm.

Part 2 of this would be posted on our stories tomorrow by 12pm. Make sure you check it out before it expires. 

Have you ever dealt with your snails dying? Tell us about your experience in the comments section below👇

node.text:
How come Plant foods are just SO BEAUTIFUL?! I just adore them. 100% want to bring those into my body and let them become me ;)
(ok that sounded a little weird but you know what i mean ..!) 😆
.
Gorge produce this week from @nourishedcommunities – who, if you are local to #Islington, #London you’re lucky – these lovely peeps’ well-stocked popup shop open days are steadily increasing (think farm #marketstall + whole food shop + #zerowasteshop combined!)
.
I just love seeing small, passionate initiatives like these take foot and steadily grow stronger as people around them understand just how lucky they are to get access to this kind of produce. And just how much small businesses like these bring to a local area 👊 #shoplocalforthewin #londonlockdown2
.
Much love, Sara x
#shisodelicious

node.text:
This week we are happy to share with you @sullifarmandkitchen 👩‍🌾 They strive to build community around food, to have relationships with the families that consume their product.  They want you to know where your food comes from, how it was produced, how it affects you, and how it affects the environment around you. 💛

@farmstandrevival’s NEWEST Featured Farm: 👍 @sullifarmandkitchen

“Here at Sullifarm, we embrace a rather full-circle scene in agriculture.  One that’s all about restoration, repair, healing and health.  We don’t just grow food, we strive to regenerate our soils and pastures in the process. 
.
Pasture-raising animals according to their natures thus creating the tastiest and healthiest food products in a local and regenerative farm setting.”

Hooks, TX
📸: @sullifarmandkitchen

node.text: We have been so busy getting the farm ready for winter but I’m happy to say we got the new greenhouse up and running right before the first snowfall of the season. It’s not perfect but I’m proud of how it came out and happy to have more space for our #microgreens 🌱Building a greenhouse from scratch was the easy part, growing in Tahoe during the winter will be the challenging part. 🌱🌱🌱 #HighAltitudeFarming
